awd_titl_txt: Change Thinking for Global Science: Fostering and Evaluating Inquiry Thinking About the Ecological Impacts of Climate Change
awd_abstract_narration: This project is developing learning progression-driven visualization technologies, curricular units, and assessments towards realizing empirical evidence about middle and high school students' complex thinking about ecological impacts of global climate change. During the lifetimes of current middle and high school students, it is likely that our planet will undergo more anthropogenic change than it has during all of human history to date. With a national interest in complex thinking for globally competitiveness, a sense of urgency exists to build a solid, research-based foundation about a new, interdisciplinary focus area within precollege science education - students' complex reasoning about the impact of global changes on ecosystem dynamics. Recognizing the need for systematic development of resources, this project builds from existing resources and utilizes a learning progression approach for the systematic design of coordinated curricular, tool and assessment products. Quasiexperimental research studies on matched and consecutive cohorts are conducted to document learning outcomes and trajectories. Cross-sectional investigations are used to determine information on the effectiveness of curricular programs on student achievement. Growth curve analysis is used to descriptively examine students' complex reasoning growth trajectories throughout curricular programs. This work provides dynamic, age-appropriate visualization and modeling tools, and associated curricular units and assessment instruments to serve as foundational, empirically based information on teaching and learning about the impacts of global climate change. This work also provides an empirical and theoretical basis for content and inquiry reasoning progressions that articulate critical concept development in science and that explain how learning development is consistent with theories of learning. Data from middle and high school students coordinated with longitudinal data from 4-6th grade students provides information on student growth trajectories and achievement outcomes that will contribute to an understanding of possible learning progressions-driven outcomes over multiple units and years. Research results will also provide insights into the character and dynamics of learning trajectories and the challenges that occur as content and reasoning knowledge develops.

Products Developed and Findings

  1. Middle and High School Learning Progressions. These were focused on Next Generation Science Knowledge (KGSK) that included science practices and content knowledge in each step. Figures 1 and 2 present our high school and middle school learning progressions. Our learning progressions are a series of stairs from bottom to top, with each stair representing a learning goal that is a fusion of disciplinary core ideas with a science practice into the NGSK goal for that lesson.
  2. Curricular units. Using the learning progressions as templates, we developed an eight-week middle school unit and a fourteen-week high school unit focused on climate change and the impacts of climate change.
  3. Interactive online portal, SPECIES, for North American delivery of scaffold-rich, interactive curricular activities and assessment system (see Figure 3-sample online scaffold system and hot links).
    1. Our accompanying online formative and summative assessment system permitted teaches’ and students’ use of near and real-time data. In particular, our online assessment system had functionality that permitted.
      1. Monitoring of Class Progress and Quality. Our online interface gave teachers access to whole class of outcomes at one time. In other words, once students enter their responses to the embedded questions, teachers can access those responses right way, including review of percentage completed or quality of answers in one view.
      2. Glossary Terms. Glossary terms were embedded as hot links to familiarize students as needed with important terminology.
      3. View, Revise and Re-save Answers.  Students could view and revise answers at all times.
      4. Strategically Simplified data and predictive distribution modeling visualizations so that students could make predictions of the impact of climate change on one or many species (see Figures 4-Predictive Distribution Modeling and 5-Greenhouse Gas Animation).
      5. Usability testing revealed that during student data collection, the number of data entries where a student identified the species of their field observation was significantly higher when they used the iPod Touch than when they used the handout and clipboard (p = .013). Students also collected significantly more detailed and accurate data when using the iPod Touch (p = .001). Data were also collected from student interviews. In their interviews, students reported higher levels of usability and enjoyment when using the iPod Touch, and were more positive about the data collection activity when using technology. A paper reporting the full results of the study is in press in Computers & Education.
      6. Impact. Our online 8 week curricular units were implemented and studied with 3654 students and 56 teachers in 11 states during this grant.
      7. Professional Development.  We conducted several 2-hour professional development webinars for our distributed teachers. For those that could not attend, we recorded and made available the entire webinar viewable on our website.
      8. Student Learning. An examination of student’s overall scores on pretest and posttest for DCI items and NGSK items through one-tailed paired t-tests.
